so technology of course can mean a lot of things as you all know for the purposes of this talk we'll be talking

that you're all very familiar with like mobile phones tablets computers television and all the content that goes

an essential mechanism for distributing information in as part of relief efforts
in response to natural and man-made disasters in addition to all of this
value we also spend a lot of time with technology and so the average American spends a little more than 10 and a half
hours a day with screen-based experiences and checks their smartphone
about a hundred and fifty times or about once every six minutes that you're awake this isn't just a phenomenon that
applies to adults today American children spend more time with screen based technology than they do in school
and this is true kind of across socio-economic strata so in low-income
communities in the u.s. for example about 75% of preschoolers own their own dedicated mobile device before they turn
four this is also true around the world so people in places like Saudi Arabia
Indonesia and Poland South Africa for example all share more content online
than we do here in the United States so we are quite engaged with these
technologies we spend a lot of time with them but these aren't always empowering experiences so there is people often
reports in terms of what's known as problematic internet use this is a pattern of engaging with Internet
connected experiences in a way that leads to destruction Olymp Airmen of daily life
this isn't just a first world problem and in fact as national quality of life
in a country goes down the incidence of problematic internet use goes up so for
example a pretty recent study on college students in Bangladesh found that about
25 percent display symptoms of pio
people say that they feel the need to check in with technology even when they know that it's going to make them feel

use today managing the way we engage with technology has become an essential part of daily life the last thing I want
to say about this before I talk about some of my work is that this is not an accident this is very much a designed
phenomenon so user engagement is a primary goal and metric for lots of tech
companies this is sometimes referred to as the attention economy or the eyeballs
economy which just means that your attention is valuable and generates
revenue for someone potentially through metrics like click-through rates or ad
impressions or time spent with a particular experience now companies have
lots of different ways of attracting and holding your attention sometimes they do
so by providing you with an experience that has value for you and sometimes
they do so by exploiting classic psychological principles that they know about you like your need to belong or
your responsiveness to variable rewards so the goal of the studies that I'm
going to be talking about today are all around this theme of how can we support users in engaging with technology only
on their own terms and in ways that they feel good about I'm going to talk about
three different projects the first is an exploration of the kinds of limits and boundaries that people want on their
technology use and then two different design projects one targeting adults and one targeting kids so this first project
on family technology rules so as the project we called not at the dinner
table which looked at how kids and family kids and parents set boundaries
on technology use at home and what they want for their family so we chose to
look at the rules that families set because rules offer this glimpse into intentions and desired behaviors so it
tells you a little bit about what behaviors people think are appropriate what they want to do it also tells you a
little bit about what behaviors are challenging what's hard to stick with so you know parents don't say to their kids
like look you're not allowed to use your phone to steal someone's identity because that's not a hard challenge for
them so it gives us a little bit of insight into what the sticky points are so he has two questions in this project
first what rules and expectations do children and their parents have for each other about technology use and then what
makes these rules and expectations easier or harder to live up to this was
a survey study we recruited 249 parent-child pairs from around the country and these are kids between the
ages of 10 and 17 and for each family we first asked of course the parents what
rules they had for their child's use of Technology and this has historically been kind of the sum total focus of
research in this space but we also kind of wanted to take a more family centric
view where we looked at how this was playing out for people of all ages so we
asked the kids what rules and expectations do you have for your parents use of technology we also asked
parents what sorts of behaviors they thought were appropriate for themselves and we asked kids what sorts of rules
they were expected to live up to and then we took all of these descriptions these open-ended descriptions of the
rules and expectations that they had and we used content analysis to cluster that in two different types of rules and
compare the properties of some of those different rules so this is a rules that we saw for kids and they clustered into
a taxonomy of twelve different categories the area of each of these dots represents how frequently that
particular type of rule came up for the people in our study the most common
types of rules for what we called be present rules these were rules about being respectful and responsive toward
the people who are physically spending time with so things like be present during events and functions and
mealtimes second most common types of rules or rules about privacy it's like I
can't give my phone number to strangers and then we saw a number of different types of rules things like content
restrictions no Grand Theft Auto so rules about what kids can and can't do with technology parent audits this is
when kids would have to like give their social media passwords to their parents or give them access to all their text
messages so that parents could check out but what kids have been doing and we saw
that these categories clustered into two overarching umbrellas that we called
activity constraints and context constraints and these were roughly came
up roughly equivalently so about the same number of rules in each of these categories so activity constraints are
rules about what kids can do with technology things like no snapchat and these are kind of all-or-nothing rules
that either say something is okay or it isn't second types of rules context
constraints were things like no phones at the dinner table which didn't ban anything outright but sort of set
contextual boundaries on when things were and weren't okay and this difference is interesting because we saw
that context constraints were much harder than activity constraints so essentially easier to just ban
something altogether than it is to set kind of nuanced boundaries on when it is it isn't okay to engage with so kids
said they were less likely to follow these types of rules parents are the they were harder to enforce and kids
told us that they required more effort so even to get to that lower level of compliance took more work I mentioned
the rules that we saw for parents briefly and again these rules clustered into a taxonomy of common themes and
again and the most common type of expectation that parents and kids alike had for adults in their family was be
present so kids said stuff like pay attention put down the phone when your child is trying to tell you something
important so the findings that came out of this that I specifically want to
build on today first where this important was the importance of presence as a kind of family value so across the
spectrum across the u.s. this was the most frequently cited rule for family
members of all ages the second is this new problem of context so historically
rules around technology use have been all about what we call activity constraints here so all about what kids
can do with technology but today about half of the rules that families are setting are about what is ok and when
and more context specific boundaries and then finally the piece that I want to
build on next and is this idea that saying no is easier than saying well
sometimes and that's interesting because we want people to be able to get the
value that they're seeking out of technology we don't want them to have to throw it to throw it out altogether and
so how can we support people in engaging with experiences that they value without
bringing along all of these side effects that they don't feel so great about so no was easier than sometimes so the
second project kind of built directly on that challenge this was a project that
we called my time to explore how smartphones might help adults in
engaging in this kind of targeted non-use that they're interested in to help them continue using their phones in
the ways that they value and maybe cut back on some aspects of phone use that they don't like so much specifically
we're asking can smart phones support users engaging only when they feel good about doing so I'm and to start we recruited a
panel of expert designers to come up with as many possible design solutions as they could these are pretty
wide-ranging but we clustered them using affinity diagramming and they fell into
a taxonomy of eight different styles of intervention so these same types of
approaches came up again and again so these were things like providing users
with information so just kind of passively surfacing information about
their usage behaviors giving them rewards for engaging in specific types of behaviors setting up barriers that
made it harder to engage and behaviors they don't feel good about and so forth then for each one of these categories we
created wireframes and storyboards with what we call category exemplars where we
tried to really get at the essence of that category so for example for this
information category we had this wire frame with a widget a kind of passively presented information about how much
time someone spent with experiences that they want to cut back on say youth this says you've been on Facebook for 28
minutes today something like that for the punishment category we came up with
this design I mean you have to like come up with some bad ideas in order to get to the good ones I think so we came up
with this design where you would choose a picture of something you don't want to see like a spider or a photo of your ex
and then as you engage in this pattern of behavior that you want to change this
image starts to appear more and more frequently on screen I don't know
then we conducted a survey with a few hundred people where we showed them all
of these different scenarios and we asked them how interested they would be in trying some of these out there were a
few that they liked and said they'd like to give a try specifically the information limit and mindfulness
categories there are a few they're kind of neutral about and weren't sure if they would try these were our
and appeal to value categories and then there are a few that they hate it or they thought there was no way they were
going for the spiders so we threw out all of these and we created a compound
intervention that combined all three of these approaches the result was an app
we called my time which lets the user select some experiences that they want
to monitor set goals about the amount of time they're gonna spend with those experiences and combines all three of
these different categories so it included this aspiration setting window
that shows up each day where you can optionally choose to say what some of your goals are for the day so as part of
our mindfulness approach as part of our information approach we had this
persistent notification in the notification shade so anytime you're engaging them with a monitored app you
can see how you've been spending your time and then as part of our limit of
setting approach whenever a user bumped up against one of those boundaries that they'd set for themselves in their
initial tracking setup this dialogue would pop up and tell them that they had
run out of time recruited 23 Android
users to participate in a deployment study we had them first fill out this
survey where they told us about their current behaviors things that they feel good about doing with their phones
things that they'd like to change and then we collected a week of baseline
data where we just passively logged everything that they did with their phone without any kind of intervention to see what they were doing and then we
did a one-week intervention deployment where they use the buy time so we saw
that our participants chose to monitor 139 different apps we took each of the
apps that they tracked and for that person compared those apps against their initial survey responses to see whether
the things that they said they felt good about using and the things they wanted to cut back on aligned with what they
chose to monitor and unsurprisingly most people chose to
track something that they had explicitly said was something they wanted to use less one thing I didn't expect was that
more than half of our participants also chose to monitor apps that they feel really good about using so they seem to
want to know for example how much time they were spending with their fitness app or managing their finances or
reading the Bible or learning a foreign language so potentially some kind of
design opportunity there to support people in some quantity quantified self behaviors around monitoring things they
like doing with their phone and then relative to their baseline use we saw that people cut back on the amount of
time they spent with their phone by about 33 minutes a day more
interestingly was where that reduction came from so on the left are people's
usage data about the amount of time people spent with the apps they feel good about using over on the right are

where we asked people each day what they wanted to do this was totally optional
people chose to set 57 different aspirations across the week that they

times up dialog showed up if the user had set an aspiration we reflected it

okay so it was exciting to see that this seemed to be effective for inducing this

others and that this kind of differentiated non use aligned with the

probably that I'm most excited about moving forward is looking beyond these

specifically we were asking can the technologies that preschoolers are engaging with support them in learning

technologies out there that are already designed to restrict children's use of technology they are broadly known as
parental controls they don't teach safe self-regulation
they instead force children to comply with limits by locking them out of different experiences so they are
designed to regulate not to support self-regulation they don't the use of
parental controls doesn't actually predict children's self-regulation later so there isn't any evidence that it

of rigid and controlling structures on kids would undermine their intrinsic motivation to self-regulate now in
contrast to parental controls you may have seen what's known as autoplay or

explicitly described as mechanisms for increasing use but there is kind of
they're kind of consistent with that sort of behavior so they're a common feature of Internet video on-demand

that background we set out to explore how we
could design a video player for kids that would help them in self-regulating
their use and actually taking that step themselves of turning it off at the end
to do so we first started with existing evidence-based curricula for preschool
that teach self-regulation in other contexts so nothing to do with technology the first curriculum that we looked at
is called tools of the mind and one of the core mechanics here is that it teaches self-regulation through what's
known as a play plan so it's super cute it has these four year olds planning out how they're gonna play and drawing
pictures of what their play is gonna be like and making these kind of goal directed choices ahead of time so here's
a play plan by Omari we also looked at the high scope curriculum which has
about sixty years of really high quality evidence behind it and has been very successful at improving kids
self-regulation in ways that persists throughout their lifetime and this
similarly is built on what's called a plan do review cycle so lots of elements
here that are similar to the way we design persuasive technologies for adults and goal-setting theory and
things like that plan do review has children kind of plan out in advance what they're going to do gives them
information as they do it about their behavior relative to their plan and then gives them the opportunity to reflect on
what they did and so we took some of those core mechanics and we created a

activity so what are they going to do when this experience ends and then they

activity that they had selected as their next activity is reflected back to them this cocoa character says to them now
